description: This allows one subclass deep to be found with yt.load
title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: Can you give an example where this will give different results?  Specifically, which frontends?
content.html: Can you give an example where this will give different results? Specifically, which frontends?

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: I don't think it has an application in yt at the moment. I am however writing a custom GDF frontend to give some custom fields when reading my GDF files, and this makes yt.load detect that frontend rather than raising the error because candidates is two long, because both the built in GDF frontend and my one will say they can load the file.
content.html: I don't think it has an application in yt at the moment. I am however writing a custom GDF frontend to give some custom fields when reading my GDF files, and this makes yt.load detect that frontend rather than raising the error because candidates is two long, because both the built in GDF frontend and my one will say they can load the file.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: The way we've dealt with this in the past is to make _is_valid in the subclass more specific than _is_valid in the superclass.  Is that not possible here?
content.html: The way we've dealt with this in the past is to make _is_valid in the subclass more specific than _is_valid in the superclass. Is that not possible here?

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: I agree this is probably worth looking into if you haven't done that yet.  I am hesitant to add an extra layer of machinery that doesn't apply to any of the existing frontends, and so cannot be fully tested.
content.html: I agree this is probably worth looking into if you haven't done that yet. I am hesitant to add an extra layer of machinery that doesn't apply to any of the existing frontends, and so cannot be fully tested.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: The more specific `_is_valid` in subclass will allow to find datasets that do **not** belong to subclass. This is the other way around. The question is how to distinguish two gdf files when one of them comes from specific code. `load()` will happily say they're both gdfs...
content.html: The more specific _is_valid in subclass will allow to find datasets that do not belong to subclass. This is the other way around. The question is how to distinguish two gdf files when one of them comes from specific code. load() will happily say they're both gdfs...

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: I have a more specific subclass `_is_valid`, but because my files are valid gdf files, the GDF frontend does, and should, return that they are valid for that frontend.
content.html: I have a more specific subclass _is_valid, but because my files are valid gdf files, the GDF frontend does, and should, return that they are valid for that frontend.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw:
Can we add logic to the vanilla GDF's _is_valid that will avoid detecting these datasets as vanilla GDF?

Another option would be to add logic to "load" so users can specify frontends they want to ignore.

The solution in this PR seems a bit brittle to me...
content.html:
Can we add logic to the vanilla GDF's _is_valid that will avoid detecting these datasets as vanilla GDF?

Another option would be to add logic to "load" so users can specify frontends they want to ignore.

The solution in this PR seems a bit brittle to me...

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw:
We could make it so that it traverses the whole subclass tree and finds the lowest subclass that returns `_is_valid`. That would be the most robust way of doing it that I can think of.

Of course, what this is doing is exactly that to a depth of 2.
content.html:
We could make it so that it traverses the whole subclass tree and finds the lowest subclass that returns _is_valid. That would be the most robust way of doing it that I can think of.

Of course, what this is doing is exactly that to a depth of 2.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: Reading this over, I rather like it.  It would also simplify the way we handle OWLS and EAGLE datasets; they could be subclasses of Gadget, and we would not falsely return Gadget datasets for them.
content.html: Reading this over, I rather like it. It would also simplify the way we handle OWLS and EAGLE datasets; they could be subclasses of Gadget, and we would not falsely return Gadget datasets for them.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw:
I have come up with this method of searching the whole class hierarchy for the lowest subclass.

https://gist.github.com/Cadair/f47acc9e9ca30035b354

It will error if it can not parse the input, which should be because the tree diverges. If people think that is a better approach I can write proper tests for it and include it here.
content.html:
I have come up with this method of searching the whole class hierarchy for the lowest subclass.

https://gist.github.com/Cadair/f47acc9e9ca30035b354

It will error if it can not parse the input, which should be because the tree diverges. If people think that is a better approach I can write proper tests for it and include it here.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw: FWIW, `OWLSDataset` is already a subclass of `GadgetHDF5Dataset`.  It looks like the data formats are sufficiently different that there isn't the same ambiguity we need to worry about here.
content.html: FWIW, OWLSDataset is already a subclass of GadgetHDF5Dataset. It looks like the data formats are sufficiently different that there isn't the same ambiguity we need to worry about here.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw:
Can you use the `issubclass` builtin rather than `inspect`?  I believe we've avoided using `inpect` in the past, but I'm fuzzy on the exact reasons why.

FWIW, I'm happy with this solution. My main objection to the original version was that it only considered the case when two frontends returned valid, this should be a better, more general solution.
content.html:
Can you use the issubclass builtin rather than inspect? I believe we've avoided using inpect in the past, but I'm fuzzy on the exact reasons why.

FWIW, I'm happy with this solution. My main objection to the original version was that it only considered the case when two frontends returned valid, this should be a better, more general solution.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw:
I am not sure how I could generate a set of the whole inheritance tree from
`issubclass`. I would probably need something like `super`? I would rather
keep using inspect because it's super easy.
content.html: I am not sure how I could generate a set of the whole inheritance tree from issubclass. I would probably need something like super? I would rather keep using inspect because it's super easy.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw:
On topic of this. 

I think @brittonsmith was around at my institute when I started developing it. I have written a custom version of the RAMSES frontend to read the chemistry fields from the RAMSES chemistry patch RAMSES-CH. at the moment, I have modified the yt.load method to include a key word argument "patch"

e.g 

```
#!python

yt.load(os.path.join('%s/output_%05d/info_%05d.txt'%(folder, ioutput, ioutput)), patch=patch)
```
and for example in the data structures


```
#!python

class RAMSESDataset(Dataset):
    _index_class = RAMSESIndex
    _field_info_class = RAMSESFieldInfo
    gamma = 1.4 # This will get replaced on hydro_fn open

    def __init__(self, filename, dataset_type='ramses',
                 fields = None, storage_filename = None, patch=None,
                 units_override=None):
```
This PR might be useful with adding in the RAMSES patches to YT (of which are not officially supported by YT yet). Although it gets a bit more complicated since RAMSES-CH is not publically available yet (although I believe I have the creators permission to publically give YT the ability to read it's fields... of which its structure may change before it's public release anyway)  RAMSES-RT is public and so could be supported by this sort of setup.
content.html:
On topic of this.

I think Britton Smith was around at my institute when I started developing it. I have written a custom version of the RAMSES frontend to read the chemistry fields from the RAMSES chemistry patch RAMSES-CH. at the moment, I have modified the yt.load method to include a key word argument "patch"

e.g 

yt.load(os.path.join('%s/output_%05d/info_%05d.txt'%(folder, ioutput, ioutput)), patch=patch)

and for example in the data structures

class RAMSESDataset(Dataset):
    _index_class = RAMSESIndex
    _field_info_class = RAMSESFieldInfo
    gamma = 1.4 # This will get replaced on hydro_fn open

    def __init__(self, filename, dataset_type='ramses',
                 fields = None, storage_filename = None, patch=None,
                 units_override=None):

This PR might be useful with adding in the RAMSES patches to YT (of which are not officially supported by YT yet). Although it gets a bit more complicated since RAMSES-CH is not publically available yet (although I believe I have the creators permission to publically give YT the ability to read it's fields... of which its structure may change before it's public release anyway) RAMSES-RT is public and so could be supported by this sort of setup.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw:
Right now there is logic in the GadgetHDF5Dataset `_is_valid` function such that if it is given an OWLS dataset, it will return False.

In principle, we could merge Stuart's PR in and make the following modification such that we will be using the new functionality to load OWLS data:


```
#!diff

diff -r 5604f5362a8f yt/frontends/gadget/data_structures.py
--- a/yt/frontends/gadget/data_structures.py    Thu Feb 05 11:54:36 2015 -0800
+++ b/yt/frontends/gadget/data_structures.py    Mon Feb 09 12:56:56 2015 -0800
@@ -338,8 +338,7 @@
     def _is_valid(self, *args, **kwargs):
         try:
             fileh = h5py.File(args[0], mode='r')
-            if "Constants" not in fileh["/"].keys() and \
-               "Header" in fileh["/"].keys():
+            if "Header" in fileh["/"].keys():
                 fileh.close()
                 return True
             fileh.close()
```

Right now the `Constants not in fileh["/"].keys()` bit is excluding OWLS data.
content.html:
Right now there is logic in the GadgetHDF5Dataset _is_valid function such that if it is given an OWLS dataset, it will return False.

In principle, we could merge Stuart's PR in and make the following modification such that we will be using the new functionality to load OWLS data:

diff -r 5604f5362a8f yt/frontends/gadget/data_structures.py
--- a/yt/frontends/gadget/data_structures.py    Thu Feb 05 11:54:36 2015 -0800
+++ b/yt/frontends/gadget/data_structures.py    Mon Feb 09 12:56:56 2015 -0800
@@ -338,8 +338,7 @@
     def _is_valid(self, *args, **kwargs):
         try:
             fileh = h5py.File(args[0], mode='r')
-            if "Constants" not in fileh["/"].keys() and \
-               "Header" in fileh["/"].keys():
+            if "Header" in fileh["/"].keys():
                 fileh.close()
                 return True
             fileh.close()

Right now the Constants not in fileh["/"].keys() bit is excluding OWLS data.

pullrequest.title: Add support for subclasses of frontends

content.raw:
Ok so I have encountered some issues with the gist I posted above, before I can continue I need to know what behaviour I should be aiming for in different situations. I know that most of these are well beyond the current requirements but still.

Assume we have this situation:
```
A - B - C
```
Where A, B and C are frontends, where C is the most specialised. The obvious answer for return is C.

In this situation:
```
A - B - C
     \
       D
```
We should throw an error, as we have two subclasses that are equally specialised but both vaild. However, what happens in this case:
```
A - B - C
     \
       D - E
```
Where the tree has diverged but one branch is more specialised than the other?
content.html:
Ok so I have encountered some issues with the gist I posted above, before I can continue I need to know what behaviour I should be aiming for in different situations. I know that most of these are well beyond the current requirements but still.

Assume we have this situation:

A - B - C

Where A, B and C are frontends, where C is the most specialised. The obvious answer for return is C.

In this situation:

A - B - C
     \
       D

We should throw an error, as we have two subclasses that are equally specialised but both vaild. However, what happens in this case:

A - B - C
     \
       D - E

Where the tree has diverged but one branch is more specialised than the other?
